query: What actions can be taken to mitigate the impacts of roads on amphibian populations?
relevant_summary: Several actions can be taken to mitigate the impacts of roads on amphibian populations. Road closures during seasonal amphibian migration have been shown to protect large numbers of amphibians from death during breeding migrations (Action 842). Human-assisted crossings involve people helping migrating amphibians across roads, with studies showing large numbers moved ranging from 7,532 toads to half a million annually, though populations still declined 64-70% over 6-10 years despite assistance and 7% of sites still had over 500 toads killed on roads (Action 784). Installing culverts or tunnels as road crossings has been widely studied, with six of seven studies finding they significantly decreased amphibian road deaths when combined with barrier fencing, though effectiveness varies by design factors including diameter, length, lighting, substrate, and presence of water (Action 884). Barrier fencing along roads, when combined with culverts, decreased amphibian road deaths in seven of eight studies, with barriers needing to be at least 0.6 m high to prevent climbing, though some species like treefrogs and 10% of common toads can still climb over barriers during breeding migrations (Action 756). Restoring habitat connectivity has shown success, with one study finding that raising a road on a viaduct to restore connectivity between wetlands significantly decreased deaths of migrating amphibians (Action 840). Installing barriers and crossing structures along roads/railways showed mixed results for reptiles, with some studies finding reduced road mortalities while others found no reduction or even increased percentages of mortalities (Action 3507).

A replicated study in Germany found that use of tunnels by fallow deer was affected by tunnel colour and design. A study in the USA found that a range of mammals used culverts, including those with shelves fastened to the sides.

Sixteen studies evaluated the effects of installing barriers and crossing structures along roads/railways on reptile populations. Five studies were in the USA, three were in each of Spain, Australia and Canada and one was in each of France and South Africa.

POPULATION RESPONSE (8 STUDIES)

Survival (8 studies): Four of seven studies (including one randomized, controlled, before-and-after study and one review) in the USA, Australia, Canada and South Africa found that installing fencing and crossing structures did not reduce road mortalities of reptiles, and in one case the percentage of mortalities may have increased. One study found that reptile road mortalities still occurred in in areas with roadside barrier walls and culverts. One replicated, before-and-after study in Canada found that following installation of tunnels and guide fencing, along with signs for motorists, there were fewer road mortalities of eastern massasauga rattlesnakes.

BEHAVIOUR (12 STUDIES)

Use (12 studies): Six studies (including two replicated studies and one review) in Spain, France, the USA and Australia found that crossing structures with fencing that were not specifically designed for wildlife were used by lizards, snakes, tortoises, turtles and alligators and ophidians. One study also found that the addition of fencing around crossing structures did not affect the number of reptile crossings. Three studies (including one replicated and one before-and-after study and one review) in the USA and Spain found that wildlife crossing structures with fencing were used by gopher tortoises and 12 snake species, American alligators and lacertid lizards. One study also found that an American alligator did not use the wildlife crossing structure. Two before-and-after studies (including one controlled study) in Canada found mixed effects of installing roadside fencing and culverts on road use by turtles and snakes. One replicated study in Spain found that use of different crossing structures depended on species group. One replicated study in Australia found that reptiles used wildlife underpasses or culverts for only 1% of road crossings. One replicated, before-and-after study in Canada found that following installation of tunnels and guide fencing, along with signs for motorists, fewer eastern massasauga rattlesnakes were found crossing the road."

query: How do different partial harvesting methods in USA forests compare to clearcutting in their impact on salamander populations?
relevant_summary:
According to research studies in USA forests, several partial harvesting methods have been compared to clearcutting for their impact on salamander populations. A meta-analysis of 24 studies in North America found that partial harvest, which included thinning, shelterwood harvesting, and harvesting groups of trees, resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting (Action 852, 851, 844). 

For thinning, studies found mixed effects on salamander abundance compared to clearcutting, with some showing higher abundance in thinned forests while others found mixed results depending on species, life stage and time since harvest. Specifically, emigrating salamanders used thinned forest significantly more than clearcuts, though thinning decreased the body condition of ensatina salamanders 10 years after harvest (Action 852).

Shelterwood harvesting compared to clearcutting resulted in higher, similar or initially higher and then similar salamander abundance in three USA studies (Action 851). However, harvesting trees in small groups did not result in higher amphibian or salamander abundance compared to clearcutting in three USA studies (Action 844).

Leave-tree harvesting, where a low density of trees is left during harvest, did not result in higher salamander abundance compared to clearcutting in two USA studies (Action 846). All partial harvesting methods studied (thinning, shelterwood, group harvesting, and leave-tree harvesting) decreased salamander abundance compared to unharvested forest areas and affected reproductive parameters such as the proportion of female salamanders carrying eggs and juveniles (Actions 852, 851, 844, 846).
